name: yarding, mobile cable yarder on trailer | cable yarding | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/11499/documentation

The inventory refers to 1 productive machine hour (PMS) - referring to the operational time of the machine including breaks up to 15 minutes - of a mobile cable yarder mounted on a trailer with an engine power of 175 kW and a total weight of 13,500 kg, including three cables (for downhill yarding) and carriage.;Cable yarding is the process of transporting logs to the landing using a stationary winching machine (a yarder) and a system of heavy wire rope. Cable yarding is primarily used on the West Coast of North America with yarder, loaders and grapple yarders, but also in Europe (Austria, Switzerland, Czech Republic, France, Italy).;These systems are best suited for steep terrain or soft soils that restrict ground operations. All cable yarding systems can move wood uphill to a landing; some systems can also bring wood downhill to the landing. Extraction distance is generally longer than with other ground-based systems and may reach over more than 600 m. Depending on the type of rigging and yarder capability, cable yarding can be used in selection harvests as well as clearcuts. ;Cable yarding systems are often paired with manual felling and processing because of the steep terrain;The inventoried mobile cable yarder incl. and cables is mounted on a trailer. The whole machinery incl. trailer has a total weight of 13,500 kg (of which 2,608 kg of cable and 385 kg of carriage), with a tower height of approximately 12 m, with an engine power of 175 kW and a maintenance factor of 0.55 (estimated based on Spielmann et al. 2007). The assumed yarding distance is 600 m.;;The third cable can be excluded from the dataset to approximate the same machinery used for "uphill" yarding.;;;;;Assumed fuel consumption: 17.5/PMH; total service life: 17,000 PMH, average daily transport distance of machinery: 6.2 km (Spielmann et al. 2007). ;Productivity depends on the specific circumstances of the harvesting operation and is specified in the respective datasets.;;The following sources have been consulted for the elaboration and plausibilisation of the dataset:;    Anonymous (2004): DIRECTIVE 2004/26/EC OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 21 April 2004 amending Directive 97/68/EC on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to measures against the emission of gaseous and particulate pollutants from internal combustion engines to be installed in non-road mobile machinery. Official Journal of the European Union: 30.4.2004 ;    Klvac, R. and A. Skoupy (2009): Characteristic fuel consumption and exhaust emissions in fully mechanized logging operations. Journal of Forest Research, 14(6): 328-334: referring to Freitas 2004.;    Klvac, R., S. Ward, P. M. O. Owende and J. Lyons (2003): Energy audit of wood harvesting systems. Scandinavian Journal of Forest Research, 18(2): 176-183.;   Markewitz, D. (2006): Fossil fuel carbon emissions from silviculture: Impacts on net carbon sequestration in forests. Forest Ecology and Management, 263: 153-161.  ;    Spielmann, M., L. Barreto, V. Erni, F. Frutig and O. Thees (2007): Life cycle assessment of energy wood chip supply chains; a case study of near future supply of forest wood chips in Switzerland (unpublished). Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI), Swiss Federal Institute for Forest, Snow and Landscape Research (WSL), Villigen, Birmensdorf.

Service beginning with the transport of the machinery to the logging site.

Includes the input of machinery infrastructure, the input of diesel fuel, lubricants/greases as well as their disposal, and the emissions into air from diesel consumption. Wood is not included in the dataset.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/02:Forestry and logging/022:Logging/0220:Logging

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Emission profile according to European legislation
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Material and fuel input from literature sources (see general comments field); air-borne emissions taken from existing dataset on diesel consumption in building machines or - where emission levels beyond applicable European legislation - estimated with emissions model based on emission limits established in European Directive 2004/ 26/EC for non-road mobile machinery types EURO IIIa and IIIb (according to Lambrecht et al 2004 and e.g. applied in Spielmann et al. 2007).

exchanges.description: Amount was scaled to 1.

flow.name: cable yarding
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/02:Forestry and logging/022:Logging/0220:Logging

exchanges.description:
emission model calculating hourly specific emissions as "engine power x load factor x base emission factor" as proposed by Lambrecht et al. (2004) and applied in Spielmann et al. (2007);  values for base emission factors for NOx for mobile machine class EUROIIIb are taken from the European Directive 2004/ 26/EC; for mobile machine class EURO IIIa values for base emission factors for NOx are calculated based on an assumed reduction of VOC emissions as compared to "Tier 2" limit for VOC of 1.0 g/kWh (following Spielmann et al. 2007).
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

(2007); values for base emission factors for particles for mobile machine classes EURO IIIa and EUROIIIb are taken from European Directive 2004/ 26/EC. Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.
